case_vignette: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of high-grade fever and generalized fatigue for 5 days. Two days ago, he developed a rash on his trunk. He returned from a family hiking trip to Montana 1 week ago. His immunization records are unavailable. His temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination shows injection of the conjunctivae bilaterally. The tongue and pharynx are erythematous. Tender cervical lymphadenopathy is present on the left. There is a macular rash over the trunk and extremities. Bilateral knee joints are swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Infectious Diseases. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a high-grade fever and general tiredness for 5 days, and two days ago I developed a rash on my trunk.
Did the rash spread to other parts of your body or is it still localized to your trunk?
The rash has spread to my extremities as well.
Do you have any other symptoms such as joint pain, swollen glands, or headache?
Yes, I have tender swollen glands on the left side of my neck and my knee joints are swollen and tender, which makes it painful to move them.
Have you recently traveled or been exposed to anyone who might have been ill?
Yes, I returned from a family hiking trip to Montana about a week ago.
Final Diagnosis: Rocky Mountain spotted fever.
